headline: Vitamin D deficiency during pregnancy may expose babies to risk of bow legs, bone deformities –Dietician
summarized_story:
Maternal vitamin D deficiency during pregnancy may expose babies to the risk of bowleg and other bone deformities, says a nutrition expert, Nwabumma Asouzu.
“Maternal vitamin D deficiency during pregnancy is a recognised risk factor for rickets and osteomalacia in infancy, which often in most cases cause bow legs and other bone deformities.
“Maximizing bone health begins with maternal health and nutrition, which influences skeletal mass and bone density in the foetus.
According to them, pregnant women and children however are particularly vulnerable to vitamin D deficiency.
They noted that vitamin D deficiency continues to be an important global health problem following its devastating health impact.

headline: People with autism deserve improved inclusion -UN
summarized_story:
The United Nations Secretary-General, António Guterres, says people with autism should be given greater support, particularly at the community level.
He said this on Friday in his message to mark the ‘World Autism Awareness Day’, and emphasised the need to reaffirm commitment to an inclusive, equitable and sustainable world for persons with the condition.
Annually, ‘World Autism Awareness Day’ is marked globally on April 2, to encourage Member States of the UN to take measures to raise awareness about people with autism throughout the world.
While the 2030 Agenda represents a commitment to reducing inequality through social, economic and political inclusion for all, including persons with disabilities, Guterres said many persons with autism still live in isolation.
“We need to ensure that the rights, perspectives and well-being of persons with disabilities, including those with autism, are an integral part of building forward better from the pandemic,” he said.

headline: UK Court Jails Adeyinka Grandson, ‘Yoruba Supremacist’, Over Attacks On Igbo, Fulani

headline: UK court jails Adeyinka Grandson for inciting genocide, spreading hate in Nigeria

Grandson, a UK-based Nigerian of Yoruba descent, is known for his social media attacks on other ethnic groups in Nigeria, notably the Igbo, Hausa and Fulani whom he had advocated violence against.
He was first arrested by the Scotland Yard Counter Terrorism Command, and the Metropolitan Police under the approval of the Westminster Magistrates’ Court in London in August 2019.
Following his arrest, the Scotland Yard Counter Terrorism Command grilled him for 9 hours, and his house was searched by the London Metropolitan Police following a warrant granted by the Westminster Magistrates’ Court.
Grandson was found guilty on 30 November 2021 of eight counts of inciting racial hatred after a trial at Southwark Crown Court.

Russian forces are creating “a complete disaster”, leaving mines around homes and even corpses, Ukraine’s president has said.
Volodymyr Zelenskyy issued the warning to his people early on Saturday as Russian troops continued to withdraw from areas around Kyiv.
The UK’s Ministry of Defence has said Ukrainian forces continue to advance against withdrawing Russian forces in the vicinity of Kyiv.
Russian forces are also reported to have withdrawn from Hostomel airport near the capital, which has been subject to fighting since the first day of the conflict.
The Ministry of Defence said that the fuel lost from the ruined oil tanks, near the Russian city of Belgorod, could worsen the supply problems hampering the Russian military.

headline: Will Smith Resigns From Academy Over Chris Rock Oscars Slap Backlash
summarized_story:
Will Smith, facing possible expulsion or suspension after he assaulted Chris Rock during last Sunday’s Oscars telecast, has instead resigned from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences.
In a statement, Smith called his actions “shocking, painful and inexcusable” and said that he will accept any additional consequences that the Academy’s Board of Governors deems appropriate.

headline: Nigeria Ready to Lead Africa’s Digital Tech Race, Buhari Says as Microsoft Opens $200m Hub in Abuja
summarized_story:
Nigeria President Muhammadu Buhari has expressed the readiness of Nigeria to lead the digital technology aspiration of the 54 African countries.
This is just as Microsoft opened its first engineering hub, the African Development Centre worth $200 million, in Abuja.
Buhari said: “I have been informed that the African Development Centre in Nigeria is Microsoft’s first engineering hub in Africa as the current investment stands at about $200 million.
The Nigerian President said: “Our emphasis on the development of our Digital Economy has also positioned the sector as a prominent factor in the Nigerian economy.
As such, we urge you to continue to support the development of our digital economy.

headline: APC Chairman Adamu Says Buhari Has ‘Given Marching Orders’ to Deliver 2023 Elections
summarized_story:
The new National chairman of the All Progressives Congress (APC) on Friday said President Buhari had given the new National Working Committee (NWC) of the party marching orders to deliver the 2023 general elections.
Adamu hinted that he would probe the national secretariat of the ruling party and its directors, stressing that there was a need to know the status of the secretariat.
The chairman said the party could not continue the way things were, adding that his administration would have zero tolerance for failure.
The chairman also noted that the leadership of the party needed the support of the Progressive Governors Forum (PGF).
He said the leadership of the party would interface with the PGF through its chairman and the Governor of Kebbi State, Atiku Bagudu.
